description:
Rutilus rutilus, commonly known as the roach, is a freshwater fish species belonging to the family Cyprinidae. It is native to Europe, where it is widely distributed in various lakes, rivers, and other inland water bodies.

The roach is a small to medium-sized fish, typically reaching a length of 20-35 cm (8-14 inches). It has a laterally compressed, elongated body with a terminal mouth and a forked tail. The coloration of the roach varies, but typically includes a silvery-green or bronze-like back, with lighter sides and a white or yellowish belly.

Rutilus rutilus is an opportunistic omnivore, feeding on a variety of aquatic organisms, including algae, plants, small invertebrates, and even some smaller fish. It plays an important role in the aquatic food web, serving as a prey species for larger predatory fish, birds, and other animals.

The roach is known for its adaptability and ability to thrive in a wide range of habitats, from slow-moving rivers and lakes to more turbid and eutrophic waters. It is considered a hardy and resilient species, capable of withstanding environmental changes and disturbances.

Rutilus rutilus is of commercial and recreational importance, as it is a common target for anglers and is also harvested for human consumption in some regions. It is considered a valuable component of many freshwater ecosystems and is an important part of the aquatic biodiversity in its native range.
